授業目的: The purpose of this course is to guide students towards developing a critical and practical appreciation of cross-cultural management (CCM) as a vital, organisation-specific response to the challenges and opportunities currently emerging in the global business environment.
到達目標:
The instructor has designed this CCM course on the professionally grounded assumption that students studying for an MBA qualification can learn most effectively when they engage in active and collaborative learning. On this basis, an overarching learning goal for this course is:
•By working actively and collaboratively through this course students should develop a critical and practical understanding of the extent to which CCM practices might differ according to specific geographical, institutional and strategic business contexts

The instructor’s preferred approach towards working with students is interactive. On this basis, and assuming students taking the course are prepared to engage actively with the learning materials, students should become more confident in:
•Demonstrating a critical appreciation of diverse social, cultural, sub-cultural and virtual identities relevant to contexts for CCM
•Making - and justifying - decisions that impact on the work and learning of people from diverse social and cultural backgrounds: e.g. in virtual project teams
•Applying skills and competencies relevant towards pursuing a global career in organisational management and business leadership
授業方法: This version of the CCM course has been designed for delivery in face-to-face and / or hybrid / hyflex modes

第1回:
What is ‘cross-cultural management’ (CCM)?
Discussion questions include:
•What is distinctive about ‘cross-cultural management’ (CCM) as a style of strategic management? How and why might CCM be distinguished (in practical terms) from processes of ‘general management’ or ‘international management’?
第2回: Developing a conceptual perspective on CCM, how can we describe and distinguish between an individual’s ‘social’, cultural’, ‘sub-cultural’ and ‘digital' (virtual) identities? In practical management terms, how might these identities overlap? In contexts for CCM, how might reference to these conceptualised identities help explain our own experiences and expectations of being ‘managed’ cross-culturally in organisations?

Homework reading (questions & exercises posted to LUNA):
•Lee-Kelley, L. and T. Sankey (2008) Global virtual teams for value creation and project success: A case study. In International Journal of Project Management 26 pp. 51-62.

LUNA discussion.
第3回:
Challenging CCM theory: assessing CCM performance
Topics for discussion include:
•Identifying and examining challenges and opportunities for CCM practice in specific organisational and strategic business contexts: e.g. management and leadership in and of virtual (global) project teams.
第5回:
CCM decision-making: sustainability as a performance objective
In a seminar-style discussion, we reflect on what we have learnt from the homework reading. We then focus on processes of CCM decision-making, further discussing conceptual linkages of 'identities' and 'subcultures' and the implications of these linkages for CCM practice: e.g. in relation to managing and working with employees and other organisational stakeholders of diverse ages, experience, gender along with individual perceptions of risk and uncertainty. Using mini-case studies ('vignettes') we examine examples of individual and collective (e.g. team / group) expectations of management / leadership.
第9回:
Developing managers for cross-cultural leadership: competencies
We distinguish in practical (e.g. team performance terms) between processes of CC management (skills focus) and CC leadership (competency focus). As a practical exercise we identify and list (e.g. in the form of an inventory) specific competencies relevant to CCM practice and performance: e.g. 'global mindset'.
How can these competencies be developed and improved; how can improved performance be measured?
第11回: CCM simulation based on a real-life expatriate experience: extended role play
第12回:
CCM Simulation - debriefing. (What have we learned?)

Briefing for the team assignment (assessed).
第13回:
Team presentations (assessed)

Instructor give s feedback on the team presentations
第14回:
CCM and global career development: the journey ahead?

Briefing for the individual report (assessed).

Course wrap-up.

Method of Criteria for Evaluation:

In-class examination (quiz) (15%): The ‘in-class quiz’ will be a time-limited closed book examination. In this quiz, students will be tested individually on their conceptual and practical understanding of key concepts that have been defined, exemplified and discussed during the first half of the course.

Team presentation (in class) (35%): The team presentation will be a time-limited assessment structured around a short case study (vignette) - provided by the instructor – that illustrates a real-life CCM situation (dilemma). For this report, students will be organized into teams. The team task is to propose and justify practical solutions to the situation applying CCM concepts and techniques. Each group will submit (online) their report on a date, by a time, and in a format to be determined by the class instructor. Each team will receive verbal feedback after their submission has been assessed.

FINAL Term paper to replace the final examination (50%)
In agreement with the instructor, students choose a topic for individual research. This term paper (individual report)
Each student is guided individually towards identifying, researching and analysing a real-life CCM challenge and opportunity. Topics are chosen by the student individually and require approval by the instructor. It is expected that the topic and its analysis should advance the professional and career development of each student.
